head.title: A Camera That Packs Its Own CD-R Drive

hedline.hl1: A Camera That Packs Its Own CD-R Drive

abstract.p: Sony's new Mavica MVC-CD1000 camera stores pictures on CD recorder that can hold up to 160 snapshnots on a recordable 3.5-inch CD; disc can be placed in a conventional CD-ROM or CD-R drive for viewing; photo (S)

block.p: If anyone needs further proof that compact disc technology is becoming as commonplace as old magnetic tape found in audio and video cassettes, look to Sony's newest Mavica digital still camera.

Its high-resolution pictures (2.1 megapixels) are not stored on conventional flash memory cards, nor on 3.5-inch floppy disks like previous models or even on Sony's own MemorySticks. Instead, the Mavica MVC-CD1000 carries a CD recorder that stores up to 160 snapshots on a recordable 3.5-inch CD.
Sony executives said the $1,300 camera, expected to be available in the United States in August, was the first of its kind.
If anyone needs further proof that compact disc technology is becoming as commonplace as old magnetic tape found in audio and video cassettes, look to Sony's newest Mavica digital still camera.

Its high-resolution pictures (2.1 megapixels) are not stored on conventional flash memory cards, nor on 3.5-inch floppy disks like previous models or even on Sony's own MemorySticks. Instead, the Mavica MVC-CD1000 carries a CD recorder that stores up to 160 snapshots on a recordable 3.5-inch CD.
Sony executives said the $1,300 camera, expected to be available in the United States in August, was the first of its kind.

Americans are believed to use as many as 260 million CD or CD-R drives on their personal computers, Sony estimates. By placing pictures directly on small high-capacity CD-R's, consumers can place the discs (about a third of the size of full-size CD's) in conventional CD-ROM and CD-R drives and view their pictures.

The CD-R's can store up to 156 megabytes of digital information, compared with a floppy disk that stores up to 1.44 megabytes and MemorySticks that have a current capacity of 64 megabytes. Perhaps the biggest benefit, Sony spokesmen said, is that the special CD-R's are relatively inexpensive, costing about $4 per disc.

Storing pictures in the camera on a CD-R shortens recording time in the Mavica, making it possible to shoot more images more rapidly than models using other storage mediums, according to Sony specifications on the camera.
Like earlier Mavicas, the MVC-CD1000 includes optical zoom and a digital image stabilization that eliminates unwanted shakes.
